text: Hey. Say I have a custom type `T` and two specific instances `t₀,t₁` of that type. I want to be able to define functions, say `f(t::T)` in a generic way, but be able to define specific implementations for `t₀`  and `t₁` . Am I right that I can't use multiple dispatch to do that cleanly?

elements.text: Hey. Say I have a custom type
of that type. I want to be able to define functions, say
in a generic way, but be able to define specific implementations for
. Am I right that I can't use multiple dispatch to do that cleanly?

text:
I'd like something like:
```f(t::T) = blah
f(t₀::T) = specific blah
f(t₁::T) = other specific blah```

elements.text:
f(t::T) = blah
f(t₀::T) = specific blah
f(t₁::T) = other specific blah

text: No, dispatch is based on the types only.

elements.text: No, dispatch is based on the types only.

text: A stupid example would be if `T==Nat`  and `t₀=0`  and `t₁=1` . Say I want to define `square(t::T) = t*t`  but because I'm looking for efficiency, I can do `square(t₀) = 0`  and `square(t₁) = 1` <@U01C3624SGJ>

elements.text: A stupid example would be if
but because I'm looking for efficiency, I can do

text: You could always use branching code with an if statement, but that might be slower? You would have to try it on your case

elements.text: You could always use branching code with an if statement, but that might be slower? You would have to try it on your case

text: <@U67SCG4HG> how would you approach that, then?

elements.text: how would you approach that, then?

text: OK for the if statement: branches here for special cases is no problem perf-wise. I just wondered if there was a way to make it "pretty", i.e. have a single unified implementation, but be able to "shadow" it with custom implementation for specific values. Thanks!

elements.text: OK for the if statement: branches here for special cases is no problem perf-wise. I just wondered if there was a way to make it "pretty", i.e. have a single unified implementation, but be able to "shadow" it with custom implementation for specific values. Thanks!

text:
<https://discourse.julialang.org/t/how-to-dispatch-by-value/43266/2>
this thread does what you want. But its not necessarily cleaner

attachments.title: How to dispatch by value?
attachments.text: Parametric types would be one solution: julia> struct Foo{T} end julia> f1=Foo{1}() Foo{1}() julia> function use_foo(f :: Foo{1}); println("1"); end use_foo (generic function with 1 method) julia> function use_foo(f :: Foo{2}); println("2"); end use_foo (generic function with 2 methods) julia> use_foo(f1) 1
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: How to dispatch by value?

elements.text: this thread does what you want. But its not necessarily cleaner

text: Ah, thanks, this package seems nice: <https://github.com/schlichtanders/WhereTraits.jl>
